questions.question: When the subject performs the action, the verb is said to be in the ___ voice.
questions.explanation: In active voice, the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: When the subject receives the action, the verb is said to be in the ___ voice.
questions.explanation: In passive voice, the subject is the receiver of the action, not the doer.

questions.question: Only ___ verbs can be changed from active to passive voice.
questions.explanation: Transitive verbs have objects, and the object becomes the subject in passive voice.

questions.question: In passive voice, the doer of the action is introduced by the word '___'.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The book was written by the author.' The agent follows 'by'.

questions.question: In simple present passive, we use is/am/are + ___.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The letter is written by him.' (is + written)

questions.question: In simple past passive, we use was/were + ___.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The letter was written by him.' (was + written)

questions.question: In simple future passive, we use will/shall + ___ + V3.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The letter will be written by him.' (will + be + written)

questions.question: In present continuous passive, we use is/am/are + ___ + V3.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The letter is being written by him.' (is + being + written)

questions.question: In present perfect passive, we use has/have + ___ + V3.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The letter has been written by him.' (has + been + written)

questions.question: In past perfect passive, we use had + ___ + V3.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The letter had been written by him.' (had + been + written)

questions.question: The ___ of the active sentence becomes the subject of the passive sentence.
questions.explanation: Active: 'She wrote a letter.' Passive: 'A letter was written by her.' The object 'a letter' becomes the subject.

questions.question: The ___ of the active sentence becomes the agent (after 'by') in the passive sentence.
questions.explanation: Active: 'She wrote a letter.' Passive: 'A letter was written by her.' The subject 'She' becomes 'by her'.

questions.question: 'She teaches English' in passive voice is 'English ___ taught by her.'
questions.explanation: Simple present active becomes simple present passive with is/am/are + V3.

questions.question: 'They built a house' in passive voice is 'A house ___ built by them.'
questions.explanation: Simple past active becomes simple past passive with was/were + V3.

questions.question: 'He will write a letter' in passive voice is 'A letter will ___ written by him.'
questions.explanation: Simple future passive uses will + be + V3.

questions.question: V1 means the ___ form of the verb.
questions.explanation: V1 is the base/present form: write, go, eat, etc.

questions.question: V2 means the ___ form of the verb (past tense).
questions.explanation: V2 is the past tense form: wrote, went, ate, etc.

questions.question: V3 means the ___ form of the verb (past participle).
questions.explanation: V3 is the past participle: written, gone, eaten, etc.

questions.question: Verbs without objects are called ___ verbs.
questions.explanation: Intransitive verbs (sleep, go, come) cannot be made passive because they have no object.

questions.question: In 'A letter is being written', the tense is present ___.
questions.explanation: is/am/are + being + V3 indicates present continuous passive.

questions.question: In 'The work has been done', the tense is present ___.
questions.explanation: has/have + been + V3 indicates present perfect passive.

questions.question: Modal verbs in passive voice are followed by ___ + V3.
questions.explanation: Example: can be done, must be completed, should be finished.

questions.question: 'The book can be read by everyone' is in ___ voice.
questions.explanation: The subject 'book' receives the action. Structure: modal + be + V3 = passive.

questions.question: In 'The letter was being written', the tense is ___ continuous passive.
questions.explanation: was/were + being + V3 indicates past continuous passive.

questions.question: In future perfect passive, we use will/shall + have + ___ + V3.
questions.explanation: Example: 'The work will have been completed.' (will + have + been + V3)

questions.question: The third form (V3) of 'write' is ___.
questions.explanation: write (V1) - wrote (V2) - written (V3)

questions.question: The third form (V3) of 'sing' is ___.
questions.explanation: sing (V1) - sang (V2) - sung (V3)

questions.question: The third form (V3) of 'take' is ___.
questions.explanation: take (V1) - took (V2) - taken (V3)

questions.question: The third form (V3) of 'give' is ___.
questions.explanation: give (V1) - gave (V2) - given (V3)

questions.question: The third form (V3) of 'do' is ___.
questions.explanation: do (V1) - did (V2) - done (V3)

questions.question: 'Let the door be opened' is in imperative ___ voice.
questions.explanation: Let + object + be + V3 is the imperative passive structure.

questions.question: When the agent is unknown or unimportant, 'by + agent' is often ___.
questions.explanation: Example: 'My wallet was stolen.' (by someone - omitted as agent is unknown)

questions.question: 'Richa carries a basket' - 'carries' is in ___ voice.
questions.explanation: The subject 'Richa' performs the action of carrying.

questions.question: 'A basket is carried by Richa' - 'is carried' is in ___ voice.
questions.explanation: The subject 'basket' receives the action. Structure shows passive.

questions.question: In the sentence 'English is taught by Stella', Stella is the ___.
questions.explanation: The agent is the person who performs the action, introduced by 'by' in passive voice.
